author: Lucas Davis The Morning Sun
title: Gorillas prepare for unbeaten Hornets
text: Gorillas prepare for unbeaten Hornets Comment Posted Oct. 7, 2015 at 10:46 PM Updated at 10:46 PM Posted Oct. 7, 2015 at 10:46 PM Pittsburg, Kan. Coming off their strongest win of the season, the road ahead doesn’t get any easier for No. 13 Pittsburg State as they travel to face No. 18 Emporia State at 2 p.m. Saturday. Last week against previously unbeaten Missouri Western State, the Gorillas found themselves in an early 27-7 hole at intermission before roaring back in the second half to earn the win in front of Gorilla Nation. Coming off their strongest win of the season, the road ahead doesn’t get any easier for No. 13 Pittsburg State as they travel to face No. 18 Emporia State at 2 p.m. Saturday. Last week against previously unbeaten Missouri Western State, the Gorillas found themselves in an early 27-7 hole at the half before roaring back in the second half to earn the win in front of Gorilla Nation. Pitt State (4-1) looks to derail the undefeated Hornets (5-0) in an attempt to win another tough matchup in hostile territory. The Gorillas are currently riding a 22-game winning streak on the road, earning a comeback win over at Washburn two weeks ago. Pitt State Offense (35.4 PPG ) The Gorilla offense is led by redshirt freshman quarterback John Roderique Jr, who has completed 78 of his 126 passes this season. Roderique has thrown for 965 yards, with five touchdowns and three interceptions. He is averaging 193 yards per game through the air and has completed 61.9 percent of his throws. A dual threat, Roderique leads the team in rushing with 393 yards on 67 carries, averaging 539 YPC. He has seven rushing touchdowns to lead the Gorillas. Running back Jeff Seybold has 376 yards on the ground this year, picking up an average of 5.3 yards each carry. His three rushing touchdowns are tied for second most on PSU with Michael Rose. Rose (185) and Jamal Tyler (113) give the Gorillas depth at the running back position. PSU wide receiver Marquise Cushon moved into fourth place on Pitt State’s all-time receiving yards and receptions last week. He has 1,963 yards on 112 grabs in his career. This season, Cushon has 20 receptions for 257 yards. The senior wideout is 37 yards shy of becoming the fourth PSU wide receiver in school history to surpass 2,000 yards. Cushon is 112 yards away from moving into third all-time in receiving and 12 catches from third in receptions for the Gorillas. Levi Copelin is second in receiving for PSU with 252 yards and a touchdown on 17 grabs. Pitt State Defense The Gorillas are giving up an average of 24.2 PPG this season, while allowing opposing offenses to gain 370 yards of offense a game. PSU defensive back Darnell Walker Jr. is second in D2 football in pass break ups (13) as well as interceptions (5), leading the Gorillas in each category. Safety Deron Washington is coming off a career-high 11 tackles last week against the Griffons and leads the Gorillas with 42 overall (24 solo). He is second on the team in pass break ups with six. Page 2 of 2 - Safety Devron Moore is right behind Washington with 39 tackles this season. His 24 solo tackles lead the Gorillas. Moore has three pass break ups and a forced fumble. PSU linebackers Spencer Brown (36) and Colby Hall (31) lead the second level in tackles. Hall is tied for second on the team in sacks with 2.5. Defensive end Heath Wilson leads the Gorillas in sacks with 4.5 for a loss of 26 yards. He has a forced fumbled this year as well. Emporia State Offense (39.2 PPG) ESU enters the contest of a 20-13 win at Lindenwood last week, having one of the top passing attacks in division II football season. They average 362 yards passing a game, good enough to be the third best team in the nation with the pass. The Hornets’ aerial assault is led by quarterback Brent Wilson, who is 146 of 201 this season for 1,763 yards and 17 touchdowns. He carries a 72.6 completion percentage with an efficiency rating of 171.2. ESU has a deep group of wide receivers, with Kavaski Ervin leading the way at 408 yards and two touchdowns on 30 receptions. He is averaging 81 yards per game. Mitchell Foote has a Hornets-high five touchdown receptions to go along with his 341 yards receiving. Emporia State’s Justin Brown (267) and Morris Williams (279) each have over 200 yards receiving this season with four touchdown catches each. The rushing attack of the Hornets is led by running back Antonio Brown, who has amassed 354 yards and three touchdowns with a 4.2 YPC average. Landon Nault is second on the team with 283 yards and three touchdowns, gaining 4.8 yards per clip. Emporia State Defense The Hornets’ defense has been susceptible to both the run and pass this season as they have given up an average of 21.8 points per game. Teams are running for 150 yards per game, while earning an average of 247 yards through the air. Their depth as a team lies at the linebacker position, with a trio leading the way for the defense. ESU linebacker Josh Monteaqudo leads the Hornet defense in tackles with 39, 22 of which are solo. He has 4 tackles-for-loss and three pass break ups. He has one interception this season. Linebacker Jason Tetuan has 33 tackles this season, 13 of which are solo, and seven having gone for a loss. Linebacker Kole Schankie has 32 tackles (16 solo) with three going for a loss. He has one sack on the season. By Lucas Davis
